5. The Emergency Response Program:
Carteret Facility's written emergency response program is based upon the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency, United States Coast Guard, Department of Transportation, Occupational Safety and health Administration and Local Emergency Planning Committee.  The plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire and police authorities and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. This plan has been submitted to and approved by the respective regulatory agencies and is reviewed on an annual basis.  The facility is subject to regular annual inspections by each of the aforementioned governmental agencies.

Additionally, to ensure that employees are adequately trained and prepared to respond to emergencies, they receive training in Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER), Emergency Action and Fire Prevention, Accidental Release Prevention, Environmental Awareness, and Terminal Safety Systems.  Employees also attend fire school and HAZWOPER refresher training.

Finally, the facility prepares for emergencies by conducting evacuation drills; annual drill exercises, and participates in area-wide drills that are conducted by governmental agencies.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
This facility complies with applicable governmental and industry standards. Kinder Morgan has a commitment to continuous improvement of our safety program.  As such, periodic reviews of the affected programs will be conducted.

VAM
Carteret Facility receives, stores, and distributes VAM, a liquid at room temperature, to both retail and wholesale customers.  VAM is used as a raw material for manufacturing polyvinyl resins, such as those used in latex paints, paper coating, adhesives, textile finishing and safety glass inter-layers. VAM is identified as a toxic liquid in the RMP and TCPA rules. VAM is received by ship, railcar predominantly, stored in atmospheric storage tanks throughout the facility, and distributed through truck and railcar. VAM operations at Carteret Facility only involve storage and transfer; no chemical reactions take place.

Butane
Carteret Facility receives butane by truck and directly blends the butane into atmospheric gasoline storage tanks as it is being offloaded at various locations throughout the facility. Butane is identified as a flammable gas (specifically, a liquefied petroleum gas [LPG]) in the RMP and TCPA rules. No dedicated butane storage vessels are in place at the facility and the only butane present is the volume remaining in piping after unloading the trucks. The Butane Blending Process is dispersed throughout the facility in approximately 11 independent locations. It is highly unlikely that a release in one location will impact other locations however, in this RMP submittal, the independent butane blending locations are reported as a one collocated single process to simplify the documentation and the auditing process for the NJ-TCPA .

3. The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps.
This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable State codes and regulations.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with applicable API and NFPA standards.  All affected employees have been thoroughly trained in accordance with 40 CFR 68.

4. Five-Year accident history:
There have been no releases of VAM or

Kinder Morgan Liquids Terminals, LLC (KMLT)  Carteret Facility is a chemicals and petroleum bulk storage and distribution facility. Carteret Facility operates two (2) processes for which the US Environmental Protection Agency's Risk Management Plan (RMP) and the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection's Toxic Catastrophe Prevention Act (TCPA) are applicable:

1. The Vinyl Acetate Monomer (VAM) Storage and Distribution Process, and
2. The Butane Blending Process

The below briefly summarizes some of the policies KMLT has in place to ensure the processes are operated in a safe and responsible manner:

1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.
The VAM Storage and Distribution Process and the Butane Blending Process were both designed in accordance with Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) with emphasis placed on release prevention and mitigation measures. In addition, KMLT has developed a written program to ensure continued compliance with the RMP Program Level 3 requirements. Examples of such programs include a management of change protocol, a mechanical integrity program and preventative maintenance plans for all critical equipment, hot work procedures and permits, operating procedures, employee and contractor training, an incident investigation protocol, and annual compliance audits. KMLT adheres to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.

Carteret Facility maintains a written emergency response program that complies with EPA, TCPA, US Coast Guard, US Department of Transportation (US DOT), Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA), and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) requirements. LEPC requirements.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.
